item.title: Federal Reserve First Audit results
item.dc:creator: @R.I.P_RSC R.I.P RSC
item.description:
@R.I.P_RSC wrote:

I didn’t bother reading all of it, just the table that is mentioned in the article. The $16 trillion claimed to be given to the banks are divided among 6 programs. 2 of those programs account for over $10 trillion, so I’ll just quote what they are:

TAF total: $3,818 billion

Auctioned one-month and three-month discount window loans to eligible depository institutions
Current balance: $0 Interest rate: 4,17% to 4,65%.

PDCF total: $8,951 billion.

Provided overnight cash loans to primary dealers against eligible collateral
[…] For example, an overnight PDCF loan of $10 billion that was renewed daily at the same level for 30 business days would result in an aggregate amount borrowed of $300 billion although the institution, in effect, borrowed only $10 billion over 30 days.
Current balance: $0

Two quotes from the article:

$16,000,000,000,000.00 had been secretly given out to US banks and corporations and foreign banks everywhere from France to Scotland.
Secretly given? The programs were announced, and were done in cooperation with the Bank of England, Canada Switzerland and the ECB. The FED even sent out press releases about these programs. So it wasn't secretly.
The Federal Reserve likes to refer to these secret bailouts as an all-inclusive loan program, but virtually none of the money has been returned and it was loaned out at 0% interest.

None of the money has been returned? Completely false! The Audit report clearly shows that the balances are currently $0 which means that either the loans have been payed back or they have been written off. According to the FED, they have been repaid:

The facility was announced on March 16, 2008, and was closed on February 1, 2010. All loans extended under this facility were repaid in full, with interest, in accordance with the terms of the facility.

Second statement of that quote is that it was loaned out at 0% interest. The average interest rate of the PDCF program was 1,5%. Hardly 0%. The PDFC program was by far the biggest, and the duration was only one day. The offered collateral was 108% of the loan.

All in all, the author(s) of this article have some explaining to do.

Read full topic

item.description:
@bowserjr2 wrote:

Greeny: I was going to do it, since the numbers seemed very strange.

item.title: Federal Reserve First Audit results
item.dc:creator: @Greeny Greeny
item.description:
@Greeny wrote:

[quote=“Pwnd, post:12, topic:458100”][quote author=Greeny link=topic=561025.msg4095024#msg4095024 date=1346745706]
It tells me you all read garbage news sources.
[/quote]Probably because all of the mainstream news sources don’t want to report on this. [/quote]

Actually it’s because it’s a load of tosh and bollocks but believe what you want, how many of you actually looked at the source the article was using?

The loans were mostly short term overnight loads - paid back the following day by the institutions. A lot of them renewed them in consecutive days, so if a bank borrowed $10B a day for 100 days that would be 1 trillion, but it was also paid back on each consecutive day, so the figures are massively misleading and wrong.

I’m all up for bashing America but atl east get your facts straight ;D

Read full topic

item.title: Federal Reserve First Audit results
item.dc:creator: @R.I.P_RSC R.I.P RSC
item.description:
@R.I.P_RSC wrote:

True in most cases. But in some cases, such as the discussion of the euro crisis, Northern Europe is seen as the counterpart of Southern Europe. Southern Europe contains pretty much all the Mediterean countries, except France. Northern Europe then starts with Austria and upwards.

So not the geographical north, but the cultural north. Although you could argue that France is culturally closer to Southern Europe.

Read full topic

item.title: Federal Reserve First Audit results
item.dc:creator: @bowserjr2 Bowser jr
item.description:
@bowserjr2 wrote:

R.I.P RSC:

North European countries are pretty stable, and although Belgium has had it’s problems with forming a government I wouldn’t worry about them. The US itself is among the list of unstable countries, I’d put them right next to countries such as Greece, Spain and Italy. Only the dollar keeps the US from falling apart.

Belgium isn’t Northern European, but Western European.
